docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton told a cheering crowd of elderly people today that they faced a clear choice in the coming election, and then went on to suggest in a long litany of not-so-subtle comparisons that they should not and would not choose the Republicans. "In lots of elections, there's a certain amount of guesswork," Mr. Clinton said at the National Council of Senior Citizens meeting here, refining a theme he has begun sounding in recent weeks. "But you know what I will do. First of all, you know that we did what we said we'd do, or we got caught trying to do it."

headline.main: Clinton Stresses What He Didn't Do (or Allow)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki has decided to veto legislation that would have required health insurance companies to pay for unlimited chiropractic services, bowing to the concerns of business groups, which contended that such a mandate would drive up insurance costs, administration officials said today. Both houses of the Legislature had passed the bill by overwhelming margins after chiropractors and their patients had mounted one of the most vocal lobbying efforts of the year. They had contended that the state licenses chiropractors to perform certain therapeutic procedures, so chiropractors should be equal under the law to physicians.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court brought a long and difficult term to an end on Monday, leaving behind rulings rich in symbolic significance for women and homosexuals while at the same time providing abundant evidence of the extent to which the Court's discourse has shifted to the right. This was a term with not one theme, but many. The Court spoke sometimes with surprising clarity, as in the 7-to-1 decision that invalidated the men-only admissions policy at the Virginia Military Institute. But it sometimes spoke in multiple voices so muddled as to be barely comprehensible, as in the six separate opinions that roamed over the First Amendment landscape in an inconclusive effort to decide whether the Government can regulate indecent programming.

headline.main: LEGACY OF A TERM -- A special report;In Supreme Court's Decisions, A Clear Voice, and a Murmur

docs.lead_paragraph: The often-testy negotiations over the state budget, which continued today, have dragged on largely because the main combatants have tied any final agreement to progress on an array of other major bills. They have tried to hold these other issues hostage to wrest concessions from their opponents on their own pet proposals and the budget itself. As a result, when the haggling over the budget breaks down, the bad feelings tend to spill over into talks on other changes. Gov. George E. Pataki, for example, does not want to put the last touches on any spending plan until he has a deal with legislative leaders on an overhaul of workers' compensation programs.

headline.main: Side Issues Are Impediments To Albany Budget Accord

docs.lead_paragraph: When the deal freeing hospital rates is signed in Albany, hospitals across the state will find themselves consolidating departments, merging with other institutions to give themselves greater bargaining power, cutting programs and services that lose money and laying off employees. Which is to say, hospitals will continue along a course they've been traveling for the last several years, only now at a greatly accelerated pace.

docs.lead_paragraph: A DOWNTOWN office building that has been nearly vacant since it was completed in 1991 has been bought, heralding a revival of one of the larger projects that stalled when the commercial real estate market here collapsed. The building, at 633 North St. Clair, just east of Michigan Avenue in an area known as River North, has been bought as a new headquarters by the American College of Surgeons for $21.5 million.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a case that could cost the Federal Government billions of dollars in breach-of- contract damages to the savings and loan industry, the Supreme Court ruled today that the Government knowingly went back on its word through accounting changes that plunged three savings and loans into insolvency. The lending institutions were trapped during the savings and loan bailout of the 1980's after regulators had induced them to assume huge liabilities to salvage other savings and loans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders have agreed on a wide-ranging plan to abolish New York's decades-old policy of setting the rates that hospitals can charge for medical care, from stitches in the emergency room to open-heart surgery. The plan is likely to initiate a new era of fierce competition in the hospital industry. Announced late Sunday night, it is a seismic shift in health care, affecting $16 billion in hospital services.

headline.main: New Era in Albany Hospital-Rate Plan

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: As New York abandons its system of setting rates for hospital services, as proposed in the state's 1997 budget, Maryland will remain the only state that sets rates through a regulatory agency. And while New York lawmakers say deregulation would drive down the state's health care costs, Maryland officials say their rate-setting has made hospital bills fairer and cheaper. In the Maryland system, which has been in effect since 1974 through a Federal waiver for Medicare and Medicaid payments, the state's Health Services Cost Review Commission sets the rate payment for services for each hospital in the state. All insurers -- Medicare, Medicaid or private companies -- pay the hospital the same amount for the same service.

headline.main: Maryland May Become Rare in Hospital Rates
